folderPicker.folderSelectErrorDetails:
An error occurred while selecting the folder.
- Check folder access permissions.
- Verify Claude app is running or restart the app.
- Ensure the folder path is correct on your system.
folderPicker.helpDetails:
• Claude Desktop app must be run at least once to create the folder
• Windows: C:\Users\[username]\.claude
• macOS: /Users/[username]/.claude or ~/.claude
• Linux: /home/[username]/.claude or ~/.claude
folderPicker.homeNotFound: Could not find .claude folder in home directory. Please select the .claude folder or a parent folder containing it.
folderPicker.invalidFolder: Cannot find Claude data in the selected folder. Please select the .claude folder.
folderPicker.newFolder: Select a new Claude folder or parent folder.
folderPicker.validationError: An error occurred while validating the folder.
settings.context.userWideDesc: These settings apply to all your projects as defaults
settingsManager.analyzer.backupDescripti: Complete backup of all settings and MCP servers
settingsManager.analyzer.backupHint: Creates a unified preset containing all your settings and MCP servers
settingsManager.analyzer.description: Understand where your Claude Code settings are stored and how they interact
settingsManager.analyzer.issues.duplicat: When the same setting exists in multiple scopes, only the highest priority scope takes effect (local > project > user). The other definitions are silently ignored, which can cause confusion.
Keep "{{key}}" only in the scope where you actually need it, and remove unused definitions to keep your configuration clear.
settingsManager.analyzer.issues.envOverr: This variable is passed to subprocesses like MCP servers and shell commands. When defined in multiple scopes, only the highest priority value is used — the others are silently ignored.
Keep "{{variable}}" in the scope that best matches its purpose, and remove duplicate definitions.
Environment variable "{{variable}}" defined in multiple scopes
settingsManager.analyzer.issues.mcpConfl: This server is defined in multiple scopes with different settings (e.g., different commands or arguments). Only the highest priority definition will be used when Claude Code starts the server.
Unify the configuration into one scope, or give each variant a different server name if you need both.
settingsManager.analyzer.issues.mcpInSet: {{count}} MCP server(s) found in {{scope}} scope's settings.json. Claude Code doesn't load MCP servers from this file, so they won't actually run.
Move them to ~/.claude.json for global servers, or create a .mcp.json in your project root for project-specific servers.
MCP servers placed in the wrong file
settingsManager.analyzer.issues.noIssues: No issues found — your settings are well configured
settingsManager.analyzer.issues.overridd: A higher priority scope defines the same setting, so the {{source}} value has no effect. This may be intentional (e.g., project overriding user defaults) or accidental.
If intentional, no action needed. Otherwise, remove "{{key}}" from {{source}} or from the overriding scope.
settingsManager.analyzer.issues.permissi: Deny rules always take precedence over allow rules. This means access to paths matching "{{pattern}}" is currently blocked, and your allow rule has no effect.
Remove from the deny list to allow access, or remove from the allow list if blocking is intended. For finer control, use more specific patterns.
"{{pattern}}" is in both allow and deny lists
settingsManager.analyzer.issues.title: Configuration Issues
settingsManager.analyzer.mcp.global: Global MCP servers available across all projects. Best for frequently used servers.
Alternatively, use presets to quickly apply common configurations to new projects.
Claude Code requires configuration files inside each project directory. There's no centralized project management from ~/.claude.
Workaround: Use symlinks to share configurations across projects:
Link project config to centralized location
settingsManager.analyzer.mcp.project: Project-specific MCP servers. Shared with team via git. Must be confirmed before use.
settingsManager.analyzer.mcp.title: MCP Server Locations
Save your MCP server configurations as presets and quickly apply them to any project.
settingsManager.analyzer.mcp.warning.des: MCP servers must be defined in ~/.claude.json (global) or .mcp.json (project). Servers in settings.json will not be recognized.
settingsManager.analyzer.mcp.warning.tit: Important: MCP servers are NOT in settings.json
settingsManager.analyzer.priority.descri: Higher priority settings override lower ones. Local settings have the highest priority.
settingsManager.analyzer.priority.title: Priority Order
settingsManager.analyzer.recommended.cur: Your current setup matches this recommendation
Your setup differs from this recommendation
settingsManager.analyzer.status.duplicat: Same settings defined in multiple scopes may cause confusion
settingsManager.analyzer.status.mcpInSet: MCP servers found in settings.json — they should be in ~/.claude.json or .mcp.json
settingsManager.analyzer.status.wellDist: Settings are properly distributed across recommended files
settingsManager.analyzer.title: Settings Analyzer
settingsManager.analyzer.whyComplex.reas: Claude Code evolved rapidly to support various use cases: individual developers, team collaboration, and enterprise deployment. Each scope (user, project, local, managed) addresses different needs.
MCP servers have their own configuration files (.mcp.json, ~/.claude.json) separate from settings.json because they require different security models and version control strategies.
The priority system (Local > Project > User > Global) allows fine-grained control, but can be confusing when settings come from multiple files.
settingsManager.analyzer.whyComplex.titl: Why is Claude Code configuration complex?
